Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI:Aerodynamics and Stability of Hawk Inspired Ornithopter Utilizing a Multi- Degree of Freedom Wing
Award.AbstractNarration:
In recent years the field of flapping flight has grown dramatically as flapping allows an aircraft or animal to achieve flight at low air speeds. The efficiency of flapping mechanisms at these low airspeeds makes them well suited for incorporation into the design of drones, more specifically micro air vehicles. This project aims to study the aerodynamics and stability of a hawk inspired aircraft to see how changes in wing motion effects performance of the aircraft. This research will be conducted at KAIST in Daejeon, South Korea in collaboration with Dr. Jae-Hung Han, an expert in the field of biologically inspired flight.

Larger birds such as eagles, hawks, and gulls are known for their low energy consumption during cruising flight. These birds are believed to use four degrees of freedom (DOFs) per wing, more than smaller, less energy efficient birds, and thus this project?s focus is on quantifying how change in design complexity, determined by the number of degrees of freedom (DOFs) in the wing, effects flight performance of an ornithopter. Flight performance in this scenario is dependent on magnitude of body forces (lift and drag), energy consumption, and stability of the ornithopter. This investigation aims to assess these three areas on an experimental ornithopter with a total of four DOFs per wing in which between one and three of the DOFs can be removed through locking mechanisms. Body forces as well as energy consumption will be measured during wind tunnel tests. Stability will be examined in a special facility at KAIST called KARPE, an indoor positioning facility with motion capture system. Ultimately the results of this study can be used to validate analytical models and computational studies that try to isolate the contribution of each DOF. This award is funded in collaboration with the National Research Foundation of Korea.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Continued development of flapping aircraft is important as it has been shown they can be more efficient than traditional rotor and fixed wing aircraft at small scales (wingspans between ~10cm and ~2m). Also, it has been proposed that small flapping aircraft have increased agility over there fixed wing counterparts.

Many flapping aircraft that imitate birds utilize one joint capable of rotation in one direction, e.g. a hinge joint, at the base of the wing. The motion produced by these types of aircraft is a highly simplified version of what occurs in a bird’s wing. One goal of the project was to see how increasing the complexity of motion of a flapping wing to be more like that of a bird’s, effects the flight performance of the ornithopter (aircraft that generates the necessary propulsion for fight through flapping). Specifically three wing motions were to be examined, flapping at the root of the wing, folding at the midpoint of the wing, and twisting of the wing. Individual impact of these motions on lift and thrust produced as well as energy consumption was of interest. This was to be investigated both analytically, using a previously developed aerodynamic model, as well as experimentally with a robot that could perform the specific wing motions in a wind tunnel. The second goal of the project was to develop a revised aerodynamic model that could better estimate lift distribution along a flapping wing.

The three motions were successfully modeled using a previously developed analytical model. This analysis indicated that inclusion of wing twist in addition to the base flapping motion caused a larger increase aerodynamic performance than inclusion of wing folding. However, wing folding does seem to have a significant impact on energy efficiency.

Furthermore, a revised aerodynamic model based on lifting line theory was developed. This model showed good agreement with experimental results already presented in the literature. The new model developed can be used for design of flapping wing aircraft as preliminary results indicate that it provides a good estimate of aerodynamic forces, with computation time that is several orders of magnitude lower than CFD.

Wind tunnel testing was conducted, however it did not produce meaningful results due to problems with the experimental setup configuration. Specifically how the flapping model was attached to the load cell. Subsequent tests could not be performed as the flapping model was damaged during transit and the first 2/3 of the travel period was spent on repairs.
